parts:
Hi o1. Today we are going to be collecting evidence for a research paper. 

# Ground rules

ABOVE ALL ELSE, if you are unsure about something, or do not have evidence from a web page supporting a claim, do not make a claim. If there is any doubt, there is no doubt.

This is research. SPEND EXTRA TIME above and beyond normal, to collect data carefully and methodically. We don't care about how long it takes, only that your research is accurate and epistemologically grounded. Care and attention to detail second only to the prior rule.

# Definitions

## Tool definition
For our project, a software tool is any discrete piece of software—be it a program, script, or web application—that is developed or substantially modified by researchers to perform specific, research-oriented computational tasks. These tasks must involve active data processing, such as analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation, where input data is dynamically created, documented, transformed, or interpreted to generate meaningful results. In contrast, products whose primary function is to simply display, store, or promote static datasets—without offering mechanisms for active computational engagement—are excluded. 

In essence, a valid software tool for our purposes is one that not only **supports research in archaeology or historical sciences** but does so by actively collecting and/or processing data rather than merely serving as a generic data repository or static interface.

It is our belief that the tools we have given you meet this criteria, however, if there is an absence of evidence supporting our belief, it is REQUIRED that you inform us of any problems. IF YOU ARE UNSURE, INDICATE IT rather than giving an answer.

# Task

I will be giving you the name or acronym of an archaeology and historical studies-related software tool which dates somewhere from 1995 onwards. 

You must build a well-formed quoted CSV inside a fenced code block with the following columns:
csv
"Tool", "Year", "Citation", "URL", "Evidence", "AI Notes"

* Tool is our key column. It is essential to be consistent in tool name, following the input we give you. If there is an issue indicate it in notes.
* Year, year from the web page, article, or source you found, n.d. is a valid entry for "no date"
* Citation
* URL, url of the resource where you found the thing. Do not use a HTML in-line citation style, give us the full url that the citation would have resolved to. Do not give us a line if there is no web page.
* Evidence, we are looking for "proof of life" of the software tool, i.e. a mention in a research paper, journal article, github commit, blog post, or any dated hit on a web page. Construe this category of proof of life broadly, but it's essential that you are *consistent* with your nomenclature here. Do not use HTML citations.
* AI notes: any notes, concerns, or uncertainties you have with the data provenance or quality. Do not use HTML citations.

DO NOT include your HTML citations in the CSV, they corrupt the data.

This is a comprehensive and systematic search. For each year, 1995 onwards, we one mention (one line) per source found. Obviously, many of these tools were created after 1995, so we'll want to expand our search by +- 1 year from any date we find. When you find a source, systematically explore adjacent years in your searches.

DO NOT extrapolate dates from sources. ONLY include dates where a source has been published in that year. We will perform all necessary inference, if you include a line for EACH valid source you find. For undated items, make a row, leave year blank, but include them.

This research requires that you be thoughtful, systematic, and take your time. You will likely need to visit EVERY SINGLE PAGE of search results for a given tool. 

To repeat back.

I'm going to give you a list of tools, one by one.
You will search for them.
For every source you find,  we want to record year, if possible, evidence (the source's category), and citation.
You MUST build a CSV with the output in your direct response to the deep research process.

Allowed sources: 
* Do try to find it's source code in published version control repos 
* do try to find scholarly literature, 
* do a general search on blog posts and social media.

When you respond with data:
RESULTS: Build the CSV of evidence you have found with  ANY mention of that tool in ANY year should be on the CSV, regardless of source. Include one line for EACH source you find.

Do you understand?

I understand your requirements fully. Before we begin, please provide me with the name or acronym of the first archaeology or historical studies-related software tool you would like me to research. I'll conduct a systematic and detailed search to collect accurate and well-documented evidence.

Understood. I will conduct a thorough and systematic search for mentions of FAIMS (Field Acquired Information Management Systems) in scholarly literature, blogs, social media, and version control repositories from 1995 onwards. I will document every piece of evidence found in a well-formed quoted CSV, ensuring accuracy and proper citation.

I will return with the collected data once the research is complete.

content.text:
{"task_violates_safety_guidelines":false,"user_def_doesnt_want_research":false,"response":"Understood. I will conduct a thorough and systematic search for mentions of FAIMS (Field Acquired Information Management Systems) in scholarly literature, blogs, social media, and version control repositories from 1995 onwards. I will document every piece of evidence found in a well-formed quoted CSV, ensuring accuracy and proper citation.

I will return with the collected data once the research is complete.","title":"FAIMS Software Tool Evidence Collection","prompt":"Conduct a comprehensive search for the FAIMS (Field Acquired Information Management Systems) software tool in archaeology and historical studies from 1995 onwards. Document any mentions of the tool in scholarly literature, blogs, social media, or version control repositories.

For each valid source found, record the following details in a well-formed quoted CSV format:
- "Tool": The name of the tool (FAIMS)
- "Year": The publication year of the source (or n.d. if no date is available)
- "Citation": The formal citation of the source
- "URL": The full URL where the source was found
- "Evidence": The category of proof of life (e.g., research paper, journal article, GitHub commit, blog post, social media mention, etc.)
- "AI Notes": Any uncertainties or additional notes regarding the source's data provenance or quality.

Ensure consistency in nomenclature, do not extrapolate dates, and include all relevant findings systematically. Search all possible sources diligently, including adjacent years for verification."}

metadata.async_task_prompt:
Conduct a comprehensive search for the FAIMS (Field Acquired Information Management Systems) software tool in archaeology and historical studies from 1995 onwards. Document any mentions of the tool in scholarly literature, blogs, social media, or version control repositories.

For each valid source found, record the following details in a well-formed quoted CSV format:
- "Tool": The name of the tool (FAIMS)
- "Year": The publication year of the source (or n.d. if no date is available)
- "Citation": The formal citation of the source
- "URL": The full URL where the source was found
- "Evidence": The category of proof of life (e.g., research paper, journal article, GitHub commit, blog post, social media mention, etc.)
- "AI Notes": Any uncertainties or additional notes regarding the source's data provenance or quality.

Ensure consistency in nomenclature, do not extrapolate dates, and include all relevant findings systematically. Search all possible sources diligently, including adjacent years for verification.

metadata.text: Articles 110 Number 77, December 2013 Creating eResearch tools for archaeologists: The Federated Archaeological Information Management Systems project NeCTAR awarded the FAIMS project, led by UNSW, approximately $950,000 to develop archaeological information management systems between June 2012 and December 2013. Although this project was conceived and initiated in an

With 40 partners drawn from the university, consulting, and government sectors from across Australia and overseas (Table 1), and total investment from NeCTAR and co-investment from partner organisations reaching over AUD$2.5M, the FAIMS project represents one of the largest international archaeology e-research initiatives undertaken to date. The enthusiastic response of the

metadata.title: (PDF) Arbitrary Offline Data Capture on All of Your Androids: The FAIMS Mobile Platform
(PDF) Arbitrary Offline Data Capture on All of Your Androids: The FAIMS Mobile Platform
metadata.text: This paper presents three key problems addressed by the Federated Archaeological Information Management Systems (FAIMS) project and presented during a Round Table session at the 2013 CAA. FAIMS is a major Australian digital infrastructure project established in 2012 to develop open source eResearch tools to improve archaeological data management. We first review existing Android GIS applications and discuss their performance and suitability for archaeological fieldwork in remote locations, before presenting the lessons of this review for FAIMS mobile application development. We then discuss the

metadata.title: 8 Building the Bazaar: Enhancing Archaeological Field Recording Through an Open Source Approach

Open Source Archaeology, edited by Andrew T. Wilson and Ben Edwards, Warsaw, Poland: De Gruyter Open Poland, 2015, pp. 111-129. https://doi.org/10.1515/9783110440171-009

metadata.title: IGC35 Abstracts
metadata.text: and phones. This app was developed together with the Field Acquired Information Management Systems (FAIMS) at Macquarie University and is based on the open source FAIMS mobile platform, which was originally designed for archaeological field data collection. The FAIMS mobile platform has proved valuable for hydrogeochemical, biogeochemical, soil and rock sample collection due to the ability to customise data collection methodologies for any field research.

metadata.title: A Mobile Data-Collection Workflow for Archaeologists - The Computational Geoarchaeology of Anthropocene Landscapes
metadata.text: The FAIMS people also offer “FAIMS-in-a-box” and other customized workflows for your project. They aren’t cheap, but they list very clear pricing for their services and hardware.

metadata.title:
Deploying an Offline, Multi-User, Mobile System for Digital Recording in the Perachora Peninsula, Greece
      -  Aarhus University
metadata.text: This article discusses the deployment of mobile data capture software developed by the Field Acquired Information Management Systems project (FAIMS Mobile) to document systematic pedestrian surface survey and legacy feature verification at the Perachora Peninsula Archaeology Project (PPAP), Greece, in 2020. FAIMS Mobile is an open-source platform that generates customized Android applications for data capture during field research. We reused and adapted two existing customizations from the FAIMS library for comprehensive digital recording of two workflows, integrating a collection of structured data, geospatial data, photos, and text. FAIMS Mobile required only modest hardware but supported
